c74object.name: bach.subs
c74object.digest: Replace or remove elements in an llll
c74object.description: Replaces or removes elements at specified addresses of an llll.

objarg.name: address
objarg.description: The initial address or addresses at which the substitution must be performed

method.name: bang
method.description: Perform the substitution with the most recently received lllls.

method.name: llll
method.description:
In first inlet: the elements received in the third inlet will be substituted in the llll.
In second inlet: the address of the elements to be replaced. The syntax depends on the value of the multi attribute: if it is 0, a single address is expected; if it is 1, an llll whose sublists are separate addresses, at which separate substitutions have to be performed, is expected. If single elements at the root level are encountered, they are treated as single-element sublist. This means that in the multiple substitutions case the lllls [1] [2 3] [4] [5] and 1 [2 3] 4 [5] are considered the same, and in both cases four substitutions are performed. Both positive and negative addresses are correctly treated, but the result can be hardly predictable when multiple substitutions are performed mixing positive and negative addresses on a single sublist.
An address is an llll providing a unique representation of the position of an element in another llll. It is a concept shared by many bach object. The address of each element of an llll's root level is simply its position counting from 1. The address of an element in a sublist is a list composed by the position of the element in the sublist, preceded by the position of the sublist in the parent llll, and so on up to the root level, as a sort of "path" to the element.
For instance, given the llll a b c [d e [f g] h i] j k the position of c is 3; the position of [d e [f g] h i] is 4; the position if e is 4 2 since to reach it it takes to go to the 4th element of the root level, which is a sublist, and to the 2nd element of that sublist. By reading the address from right to left, it can be seen that this is equivalent to saying that the pointed element is the 2nd of the 4th. Likewise, in the above llll f has the address 4 3 1 since it is the 1st of the 3rd of the 4th.
If the address points to a non-existing positions, the necessary elements will be created as empty sublists whenever possible. Impossible substitutions are ignored. In third inlet: the elements to substitute to the existing ones. The exact syntax depends on the value of the multi attribute: if it is 0, a single sequence of elements is expected; if it is 1, an llll whose sublists are separate sequence of elements, each to be inserted at the corresponding given address, is expected. If single elements at the root level are encountered, they are treated as single-element sublist. This means that in the multiple substitutions case the lllls [a] [b c] [d] [e] and a [b c] d [e] are considered the same. If less replacement sequences than addresses are provided, the last sequence is repeated over and over. This is especially useful to substitute the same sequence at many addresses, as providing the sequence only once is enough. If more sequences than addresses are provided, the exceeding sequences are ignored. In any case, an empty sequence (that is, null if the multi attribute is 0, or an empty sublist otherwise) causes the elements pointed by the corresponding address to be removed.

attribute.name: multi
attribute.description: When set to 1, multiple substitutions can be performed. This changes the syntax for the second and third inlets - see the description of the llll message.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

attribute.name: set
attribute.description: The set attribute allows setting the insertion elements. This is especially useful when used in the object box.

attribute.name: sizes
attribute.description: The number of consecutive elements that have to be removed by the original list, to be replaced by one sequence. Defaults to 1. When set to 0 for a given substitution, the number of removed elements will match the size of the replacement sequence. A value for each substitution is expected. However, if less values than addresses are provided, the last value is repeated over and over.
